terms.definition: The year the Transfer of Property Act was enacted in India.
The year the Code of Civil Procedure and the Registration Act were enacted in India.
A legal professional who represents clients in court and advises them on legal matters.
One of the oldest and most important high courts in India, having jurisdiction over the states of Maharashtra and Goa, and the Union Territories of Daman and Diu and Dadra and Nagar Haveli.

terms.term: Cheating and Dishonestly Inducing Delivery of Property
terms.definition: A criminal offense involving deception to trick someone into handing over property, resulting in wrongful gain for the deceiver or wrongful loss for the victim.
The primary law governing the procedure for civil lawsuits in India, detailing how civil cases are to be conducted.
The unlawful entry into or remaining upon someone else's property with the intent to commit an offense, intimidate, insult, or annoy the owner.
A legal principle stating that during the pendency of a lawsuit concerning a property, that property cannot be transferred or otherwise dealt with so as to affect the rights of any party to the suit.
The illegal act of creating a false document or altering an existing one with intent to deceive, where the document has monetary or legal value.
Papers or records created or altered dishonestly with the intent to deceive or gain an unfair advantage.
The system of laws governing India, derived from various sources including statutes, judicial precedents, and customary practices.
The main criminal code of India, defining various offenses and prescribing punishments for them.
A assertion of ownership or interest in a property that lacks legal basis or proper supporting documentation.
An Indian law enacted in 1882 that regulates the transfer of property between living persons.
Holding or occupying property without legal right, permission, or title from the rightful owner.
Legal actions, where civil proceedings deal with disputes between individuals or organizations, and criminal proceedings involve prosecution by the state for offenses against society.
A court that has the legal authority and jurisdiction to hear and decide a particular type of case.
Government bodies or officials empowered to manage land records, taxation, and urban planning within their jurisdiction.
The local government office responsible for registering property transactions and other legal documents.
The process by which the state initiates legal proceedings against a person accused of a crime.
A claim or liability against a property that lessens its value or restricts its transfer, such as a mortgage, lien, or easement.
The act of formally initiating a legal case or lawsuit in a court of law.
The punishment of being confined in prison as a penalty for a crime.
Assertions of property ownership that are not legally sound or cannot be substantiated by proper documentation or law.
The legal entitlements and avenues available to individuals to seek redress or enforce their rights through the judicial system.
A legally valid and properly executed document that officially transfers ownership of a property from a seller to a buyer.
Having no legal force or effect; invalid from the beginning.
The legal right to possess, use, dispose of, and exclude others from a property or asset.
The punishments or penalties that result from committing a criminal offense.
An act that is legally defined as a crime and carries a penalty or punishment if proven.
A legal document, officially recorded with a government authority, that transfers the ownership of property from one party to another.
The person or entity who legally possesses and has legitimate title to a property or asset.
Any legal paper or instrument used to convey ownership or rights from one party to another.
A legally sound and effective conveyance of property rights from one party to another, meeting all statutory requirements.
A legal agreement or act that has no legal effect and cannot be enforced by a court of law.
A legal term meaning that statements or offers made cannot be used as evidence against the person making them in future legal proceedings.
